7 <randymarsh9> what's the proper way to administer a remote linux server?
7 <aeyxa> ssh
7 <phogg> randymarsh9: Hire me to use ssh.
7 <randymarsh9> phogg: do you take bitcoin
7 <phogg> randymarsh9: no, I take payment only in Linux support. That YOU provide, later.
7 <phogg> to other people
7 <randymarsh9> what is ssh file transfer protocol claled
7 <aeyxa> sftp
7 <SporkWitch> scp
7 <phogg> sftp > scp, but sure you can use scp too
7 <randymarsh9> ok i want to use scp but whenever i try to edit move file i gaet access denied
7 <randymarsh9> only root has access to modify those files
7 <SporkWitch> you've answered your own question then
7 <randymarsh9> i can't login as root though
7 <randymarsh9> there's gotta be a simple way to do this without changing folder permissions everytime
7 <randymarsh9> i know how from ssh but want to do the same from scp
7 <aeyxa> There is, you log in as root
7 <randymarsh9> no, i turned that shit off because some stupid security blog told me it's the right thing to do
7 <randymarsh9> you are basically telling me the hard way to do it
7 <randymarsh9> i already know how to do it the hard way i was looking for something easier through scpS
7 <randymarsh9> telling me to login as root is hardly an answer
7 <aeyxa> randymarsh9: Log in as your user, then sudo up to root
7 <randymarsh9> aeyxa: how do you sudo up in scp
7 <aeyxa> randymarsh9: What files are you moving, where are you moving them from, what have you tried.
7 <randymarsh9> aeyxa: want to edit files in /etc/
7 <aeyxa> randymarsh9: Do you have permission to use the root account?
7 randymarsh9> yes, but the login through scp with root is turned off
7 <aeyxa> randymarsh9: If you only want to edit files, I don't know why you're asking about scp and sftp.
7 <randymarsh9> aeyxa: because if i do it through scp i'm able to use the gui
